text: ^ Speaking of which, what's the current status on ahead-of-time compilation of Julia? Is it possible to take functions without dependencies on the Julia runtime, like `f(x::Int32) = 2*x + 1`, and compile them to a shared library (the equivalent of `extern 'C' int f(int x) { return 2*x + 1; }`)? I ask because I often use Julia's metaprogramming capabilities to generate code that evaluates special functions, and it's much more ergonomic to build Julia `Expr` trees than generate C source code

elements.text: ^ Speaking of which, what's the current status on ahead-of-time compilation of Julia? Is it possible to take functions without dependencies on the Julia runtime, like
, and compile them to a shared library (the equivalent of
)? I ask because I often use Julia's metaprogramming capabilities to generate code that evaluates special functions, and it's much more ergonomic to build Julia
trees than generate C source code

text:
No. Currently the Julia runtime is required. It is possible to create a shareable libraries and provide function pointers for other software to call Julia functions.
<https://github.com/JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl>

elements.text: No. Currently the Julia runtime is required. It is possible to create a shareable libraries and provide function pointers for other software to call Julia functions.

Only C-(Auto)code generation would be helpful in case the algorithm need to run on embedded hardware.
This would be the equivalent of the MATLAB Embedded Coder.
I could not find something like this for Julia
